repository.corpname: M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections & Archives

did.abstract: The Henry T. Hettger Papers document Hettger's published and unpublished contributions to various numismatic publications, his coin purchases, and various correspondence.
did.physloc: The materials are located onsite in the department.

scopecontent.head: Content Description
scopecontent.p: Published and unpublished manuscripts written by Hettinger, periodical clippings, related correspondence and research materials

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by Cheyenne Watson in 2023.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Henry T. Hettger donated all materials in this collection in March 2023.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to this collection is unrestricted.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: This page may contain links to digital objects. Access to these images and the technical capacity to download them does not imply permission for re-use. Digital objects may be used freely for personal reference use, referred to, or linked to from other web sites.
Researchers do not have permission to publish or disseminate material from these collections without permission from an archivist and/or the copyright holder.

The researcher assumes full responsibility for conforming to the laws of copyright. The Department of Special Collections and Archives is eager to hear from any copyright owners who are not properly identified so that appropriate information may be provided in the future.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred citation for this material is as follows:

Identification of specific item, series, box, folder, Henry T. Hettger Papers, 1976-2016. University Libraries, University at Albany, State University of New York (hereafter referred to as the Hettger Papers).

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: The collection is largely organized chronologically and separated based on publication status. Most articles were stapled together with related materials (research materials, original manuscripts, relevant correspondence, published clippingsâ€¦). The donor/creator made notes about article status, but could not always recall if an article had been published. If an article was more likely to be unpublished, it was placed in an 'unpublished' folder. If an article was more likely to be published, it was placed in a 'published' folder. Larger research projects were placed in their own folders and labeled by title. Correspondence not related to article creation was placed in a separate folder.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Henry T. Hettger received an MPA from the University at Albany in 1968. After graduating, he worked extensively in the field of government and private sectors, including a brief assignment with the Office of Presidential Personnel and President Carter's Affirmative Action Project in 1977 before becoming a researcher for the National Archives and Records Administration.

At the age of 12, Henry Hettger inherited his grandfather's coin collection. This sparked a lifelong love of numismatics. Alongside avid coin collecting, he has authored over 100 articles for Numismatic News, collector newsletters, and Open Archeology, a peer-reviewed journal. He is also a member of the Early American Coppers club and particularly interested in large cents.
